urn:contentItem:6G93-TR93-RWHM-84HG-00000-00WEEKLY RECAP: CENTRAL EUROPEAN UNIVERSITY NEWS THIS PAST WEEK JUL 17, 20252025-07-18T00:00:00Z2025-09-09T21:08:37ZLexisNexisWEEKLY RECAP: CENTRAL EUROPEAN UNIVERSITY NEWS THIS PAST WEEK JUL 17, 2025

+ CENTRAL EUROPEAN UNIVERSITY [6 Press Releases]

+ NEW DATA SET ADVANCES CEU RESEARCH MAPPING OF NATURE-BASED SOLUTIONS WORLDWIDE

In an ongoing effort to explore the potential of nature-based solutions (NBS) at the landscape level, CEU's NATURESCAPES project team, from the Department of Environmental Sciences and Policy, developed a new data set of nearly 400 projects across 30 functional urban areas worldwide. NATURESCAPES is an EU-funded Horizon Europe research project, exploring synergies and trade-offs between NBS within landscapes, and their transformative potential for climate, nature and social justice.

Source: Company Website

+ NEW BOOK RELEASES BY CEU ACADEMIC STAFF AND RESEARCHERS

Here is a selection of the newest titles from  CEU's academic staff  and researchers. Books were published on topics ranging  from  digitalization and migration  to discriminatory legislation and more.  

Source: Company Website

+ CENTRAL EUROPEAN UNIVERSITY: DEMOCRACY IN QUESTION: MICHAEL IGNATIEFF ON THE CONTRADICTIONS OF LIBERAL DEMOCRACY

The latest episode of the Democracy in Question podcast, hosted by CEU President and Rector Shalini Randeria, features CEU Professor Michael Ignatieff who served as President and Rector of the university between 2016 and 2021.

Ignatieff came to CEU after serving as Edward R. Murrow Chair of Press, Politics, and Public Policy at Harvard University's John F. Kennedy School of Government. An international commentator on contemporary issues of democracy, human rights, and governance and a Canadian citizen, Ignatieff is also an award-winning writer, teacher, former politician, and historian with a deep knowledge of Central and Eastern Europe.

Source: Company Website

+ CEU OPEN SOCIETY PRIZE AWARDED TO RUSSIAN OPPOSITION FIGURE YULIA NAVALNAYA

The prestigious Open Society Prize of the Central European University (CEU) is being awarded this year to Russian opposition figure Yulia Navalnaya, widow of long-time regime critic Alexei Navalny, who was murdered in a Russian penal colony last year. Instead of her, their daughter Daria accepted the award during a gala dinner in Vienna on June 21st.

In her laudatio, Prof. Shalini Randeria, President and Rector of CEU said: "Yulia Navalnaya experienced the full scale and cruelty of political repression and persecution, she has emerged as a resolute and courageous leader in the struggle against authoritarianism and corruption. She has become a powerful voice for justice, dignity, and democratic reform in Russia. By awarding its most prestigious prize to Yulia Navalnaya, CEU honors her fearless advocacy, her unwavering defense of human rights, and her steadfast commitment to upholding the ideals of an open society against brutal repression by a dictatorship."

Source: Company Website

+ CENTRAL EUROPEAN UNIVERSITY: EARLY STAGE RESEARCHERS AND FACULTY NETWORK FOR COLLABORATION AND GROWTH

A network of early stage researchers and faculty focused on political behavior has been growing over the last three years as the result of a bottom-up thematic initiative addressing Democracy in the 21st  Century. Funded by CIVICA, an alliance of ten leading European social science institutions, the research network hosts an annual convening - the CIVICA Political Behavior and Institutions (PoBI) conference - which, this year, took place at CEU on May 26.

Source: Company Website

+ CEU CELEBRATES THE CLASS OF 2025 DURING ITS 34TH COMMENCEMENT CEREMONY

On June 20, 563 students were conferred at  CEU's 34th  graduation ceremony in Vienna's Stadthalle, with 67 students from undergraduate programs, 439 from master's programs, 47 from doctoral programs, and 10 receiving non-degree certificates.

Source: Company Website

urn:contentItem:6GFJ-WJN3-RRRX-F1GX-00000-00Updated: August 05, 2025: BlueOrchard Finance Limited: BlueOrchard-managed private equity fund invests in flood forecasting leader Previsico and other recent news2025-08-08T00:00:00Z2025-09-09T21:08:37ZLexisNexisANNOUNCEMENTSUpdated: August 05, 2025: BlueOrchard Finance Limited: BlueOrchard-managed private equity fund invests in flood forecasting leader Previsico and other recent news

Flooding continues to pose a significant financial risk globally, with losses from pluvial and ordinary watercourse flooding estimated at USD 87 billion in the first three quarters of 2024 alone, and projections suggesting annual losses could reach USD 850 billion by 2050. The increasing frequency of localised natural disasters is driving demand for advanced predictive solutions - an area where Previsico excels.

Previsico's proprietary platform aggregates diverse datasets - including live sensor, satellite, and weather data - to deliver highly accurate, property-level surface water flood forecasts and warnings up to 48 hours in advance. These insights support insurers, utilities, property owners, and public authorities in mitigating risk and minimising losses, providing a level of accuracy and granularity that sets Previsico apart from traditional forecasting models.

Having established its commercial credibility in the UK market, Previsico has validated its technology through projects in the US, Kenya, and Italy. With growth capital from Burnt Island Ventures, Previsico is accelerating its US market expansion, and with the support of IIF II, the company will deepen its reach in high-growth emerging markets, where protection gaps and demand for climate resilience are most acute.

SECTION 2 PRESS RELEASES: 2025

July 09: BlueOrchard Finance Limited: BlueOrchard launches innovative public debt impact strategy, attracting investment from leading Japanese insurer

With a fund size of JPY 20 billion (USD 140 million), Orchard 2025 invests in impact bonds that promote environmental and social benefits, in accordance with Article 9 of the EU Sustainable Finance Disclosure Regulation (SFDR). These investments contribute to several UN Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). Orchard 2025's objectives emphasise allocating the substantial majority of its portfolio to sustainable investments that support the transition to a low-carbon economy and reduce carbon emissions through climate mitigation solutions. The Fund also invests in sustainable projects that enhance financial inclusion and improve access to essential services for underserved communities.

Zenkyoren's group company, Norinchukin Zenkyoren Asset Management Co., Ltd., serves as an investment advisor to the Fund, providing credit analysis, monitoring of portfolio constituents, and investment advice.

BlueOrchard, a pioneer in public markets impact investing, has recently surpassed the milestone of USD 1 billion in assets under management in its public debt strategies, underscoring the excellence of BlueOrchard's portfolio management approach. Orchard 2025 represents BlueOrchard's third innovative strategy in Japan, highlighting the company's capability to create strategies addressing client-specific needs. Additionally, the strategy offers significant flexibility through in USD, EURO, and GBP denominated public debt portfolio, using derivatives that allow the creation of stable cash flow streams in the investor's preferred currency.

Source: Company Website

April 10: BlueOrchard appoints Michael Wehrle as Chief Executive Officer

The Board of BlueOrchard has appointed Michael Wehrle, Head of Investment Solutions & Private Equity at BlueOrchard and member of the Executive Management Team, as Chief Executive Officer, succeeding Philipp Mueller, subject to regulatory approval. BlueOrchard's Chief Impact and Blended Finance Officer, Maria Teresa Zappia, has been nominated to join the Board of Directors at the upcoming General Assembly, subject to pre-approval of the regulator.

Michael joined the business in 2021. He is currently responsible for overseeing the portfolio management and asset allocation of the firm's funds and mandates, as well as the development of product solutions. Additionally, he chairs several Investment Committees. Michael has over 20 years of comprehensive knowledge and substantial experience in the management of investments across public and private markets. Prior to joining BlueOrchard, Michael held various management roles at Partners Group in Switzerland and the UK. He is a CFA Charterholder and holds a Master's degree in Banking & Finance from the University of Zurich.

Source: Company Website

SECTION 3 OTHER NEWS: 2025

January 29: BlueOrchard Finance Limited: Nature-based Solutions: Fostering integrity for meaningful environmental and community benefits

Natural capital refers to the stock of natural resources (e.g. forests, plants, animals, air, water, soils, minerals) that combine to yield a flow of benefits to people[1], known as ecosystem services. These services fall into three main categories: provisioning services (such as food, timber, and energy), regulating and maintenance services (such as hazard protection), and cultural services (like tourism and well-being)[2]. Over the past few decades, human activities have led to a significant degradation of natural capital. It is estimated that approximately three-quarters of the Earth's land and nearly two-thirds of its marine environment have been substantially altered by human impact[3]. Nature-Based Solutions present a significant opportunity to halt this degradation and promote the regeneration of these vital resources, while simultaneously offering appealing investment opportunities. Source: Company Website

urn:contentItem:6G64-76Y3-RRRD-32K3-00000-00WEEKLY RECAP: WAGENINGEN UNIVERSITY & RESEARCH NEWS THIS PAST WEEK JUL 03, 20252025-07-04T00:00:00Z2025-09-09T21:08:37ZLexisNexisWEEKLY RECAP: WAGENINGEN UNIVERSITY & RESEARCH NEWS THIS PAST WEEK JUL 03, 2025

+ WAGENINGEN UNIVERSITY & RESEARCH [5 Press Releases]

+ WAGENINGEN UNIVERSITY & RESEARCH: FROM UNIVERSITY IDEA TO EDTECH SUCCESS: THE SPIN-OFF STORY OF WAGENINGEN UNIVERSITY & RESEARCH AND PEEK

How does a successful spin-off emerge from a university setting? As part of the Co-Creation Lab, where we explore the conditions and success factors for effective co-creation, we spoke with Maurits Burgering (Wageningen University & Research) and Gerwald van de Munt (Peek) about how a local educational challenge evolved into a widely applicable EdTech solution.

Peek is a company that originated from a concrete problem faced by a university lecturer: field trips are valuable, but often time-consuming and labour-intensive. Moreover, it can be difficult to assess their true impact, are participants genuinely learning? This challenge sparked the idea for an app that enables interactive excursions, allowing users to learn actively about landscapes and their surroundings. That idea eventually developed into an independent and innovative EdTech company, with Wageningen University & Research (WUR) as one of its clients.

Source: Company Website

+ WAGENINGEN UNIVERSITY & RESEARCH: YOUTH TAKE THE LEAD IN NATURE-BASED FOOD SYSTEM SOLUTIONS

With the accelerating impacts of climate change, biodiversity loss, and food insecurity, countries around the world are urgently rethinking the way food is produced, processed, and consumed. One promising approach rising to the forefront is Nature-based Solutions (NBS), which are strategies that work with ecosystems to address societal challenges while enhancing resilience, sustainability, and equity.

In this context, the 2025 Food Systems Innovation Challenge - Nature-based Solutions edition invites student teams from 12 countries to co-create and implement NbS projects tailored to their local realities. Organised by Wageningen University & Research (WUR) and the Netherlands Food Partnership (NFP), the challenge aims to nurture entrepreneurial thinking and hands-on learning among future food system leaders.

Nature-based solutions are increasingly critical in addressing food security and climate issues," explains Mirjam Troost, coordinator from WUR. "We want to share our knowledge from WUR and help spread awareness of the importance of applying NBS in food systems, especially through youth engagement

Source: Company Website

+ WAGENINGEN UNIVERSITY & RESEARCH: ANIMAL-FRIENDLY LIVESTOCK FARMING COVENANT SIGNED

The Animal-Friendly Livestock Farming Covenant follows on from the Animals Act adopted last year, which stipulates that animal husbandry must be 'humane' by 2040 at the latest. The exact meaning of this concept has been specified in sector plans for the four largest sectors: pigs, poultry, cows, and a plan for calves that is still to be finalized. Legally, the agreements are enshrined in a so-called Order in Council, which has been open for consultation since last week.

WUR is one of the parties that has been consulted. Quite a precarious role, according to Livestock researcher Karel de Greef: 'Our task is to investigate and, on that basis, interpret how animals function, how they experience things, how animal husbandry can accommodate this and whether - and how - any shortcomings can be compensated for. We can indicate the bandwidths: when do we see signs of positive welfare in animals, at what values do we observe discomfort, and at what point can there be damage to welfare or health? But ultimately, it is up to politicians to set the standard.'

'Setting standards is a political choice,' agrees animal researcher Fleur Hoorweg, 'but the scientific perspective is necessary in order to set standards properly. The needs of the animal do not stand alone. There are other interests that come into play in such a covenant, such as economic considerations, practical feasibility, and environmental impact. It is up to us as animal scientists to identify the consequences of certain policy choices on animal welfare.'

Source: Company Website

+ WAGENINGEN UNIVERSITY & RESEARCH: PEOPLE LIVING IN POVERTY TRAPPED IN A WEB OF FAST FOOD AND PROCESSED FOOD

People on a limited income are more likely to choose unhealthy and processed foods. This is not always a conscious choice, according to new research from WUR. Financial stress, food availability and learned eating habits put poorer population groups at a disadvantage by definition.

Scientists set out to investigate why it is so difficult for people with little money to eat healthily and how this situation can be improved. It is not a question of unwillingness, it turns out. 'It is a complex system', says postdoctoral researcher Sanne Djojosoeparto (Consumption and Healthy Lifestyle).

Source: Company Website

+ WAGENINGEN UNIVERSITY & RESEARCH: SJOUKJE HEIMOVAARA JOINS NATURALIS SUPERVISORY BOARD

Sjoukje Heimovaara, President of Wageningen University & Research (WUR), will join the supervisory board of Naturalis Biodiversity Center from 24 June. This is a secondary position. Her main role remains as President of WUR.

Source: Company Website

urn:contentItem:6G4M-DX83-S1PJ-01S5-00000-00WEEKLY RECAP: NATURE CONSERVANCY NEWS THIS PAST WEEK JUN 26, 20252025-06-27T00:00:00Z2025-09-09T21:08:37ZLexisNexisWEEKLY RECAP: NATURE CONSERVANCY NEWS THIS PAST WEEK JUN 26, 2025

+ NATURE CONSERVANCY [10 Press Releases]

+ THE NATURE CONSERVANCY RECEIVES GRANT TO PURCHASE NEW WATER TANK FOR PRESCRIBED FIRE MANAGEMENT

The Nature Conservancy (TNC) in Pennsylvania today announced it received new funding to support prescribed fire work in the Commonwealth. The Foxwynd Foundation awarded TNC a $10,000 grant to fund the purchase of a water tank and pump for fire suppression during controlled burns.

The new tank has the capacity to carry and pump approximately 70 gallons of water. It is outfitted to attach to off-road UTVs for transport into the backcountry forests of Pennsylvania.

Source: Company Website

+ NATURE CONSERVANCY TNC URGES OHIO LEGISLATURE TO FULLY FUND H2OHIO

The Nature Conservancy (TNC) today called on members of the Ohio Legislature to fully fund the H2Ohio program and continue a vital investment in the state's water quality and infrastructure.

"If H2Ohio isn't fully funded, it will cripple our state's ability to address the chronic harmful algal blooms that plague our waterways, including Lake Erie, and the outdoor recreation economy it supports," said Bill Stanley, state director for TNC in Ohio. "We are urging the Legislature to restore funding to this critical program and are encouraging Ohioans to contact your local lawmaker and tell them to fully fund H2Ohio."

Source: Company Website

+ NATURE CONSERVANCY RIGHTSIZING REFORESTATION: NEW MAPS SHOW WE CAN'T PUT TREES EVERYWHERE

From vast tracts of wilderness to city streets and our own backyards, restoring trees has long been recognised as a powerful option for limiting the impacts of global warming. Reforestation can absorb and store atmospheric carbon, while also supporting nature's recovery.

Source: Company Website

+ NATURE CONSERVANCY UVA WISE AND THE NATURE CONSERVANCY ANNOUNCE CUMBERLAND FOREST COMMUNITY FUND AWARD RECIPIENTS

The Cumberland Forest Community Fund is pleased to announce the recipients of its 2025 grant awards, with a total of $140,000 allocated to support seven impactful projects across Southwest Virginia. Selected through a competitive review process, these projects enhance environmental quality, strengthen community capacity and promote regional economic resilience.

"This year's awardees are driving crucial work in environmental stewardship, public access and placemaking," said Brad Kreps, director of The Nature Conservancy's Clinch Valley Program. "Their projects align with our mission to deepen connections between people and nature, creating lasting benefits like healthier ecosystems and vibrant community spaces. The impact of these funds, and their role in strengthening the capacity of each organization, grows every year as the Cumberland Forest Community Fund evolves."

Source: Company Website

+ NATURE CONSERVANCY GLOBAL INVESTMENTS IN NATURE-BASED SOLUTIONS FOR WATER SECURITY DOUBLED OVER THE PAST DECADE

The most comprehensive assessment ever published of money flowing into nature-based solutions (NbS) for water security reveals that total investment in this sector doubled over the decade 2013-2023-growing from ~US$22.4B in 2013 to ~$49B by the end of this timeframe.

Published by The Nature Conservancy (TNC) and Forest Trends, the new report Doubling Down on Nature: State of Investment in Nature-based Solutions for Water Security, 2025 underlines growing confidence in the power of these approaches among investors and policymakers. While the sector is dominated by government funding (97%), the findings highlight the accelerating rate at which private finance is rising while also showing how even major economic slowdowns like the COVID pandemic failed to dampen this growing interest.

Source: Company Website

+ THE NATURE CONSERVANCY CONSERVES SALMON HABITAT WITH LEMHI VALLEY CONSERVATION EASEMENT

Young Snake River salmon will have a better start in life thanks to a conservation easement recently secured by The Nature Conservancy (TNC) on the 181-acre Peterson Ranch in the Lemhi Valley. A conservation easement is a voluntary agreement that permanently protects the natural and ecological values of a property. Owners of the ranch agreed to restrict development on their property and committed to engage in significant river restoration efforts on Hayden Creek and the reach of the Lemhi River located on the ranch.

Source: Company Website

+ EVENTS CALENDAR: NATURE CONSERVANCY CEO STATEMENT: "FOSTERING A HEALTHY, RESILIENT OCEAN AT THE UN OCEAN CONFERENCE"

Ten years after COP21 and the Paris Agreement, the third UN Ocean Conference (UNOC3) will bring together UN Member States, specialized agencies, civil society, the private sector and international donors in Nice, France from June 9 to 13. Together, we will work to accelerate action to conserve and sustainably use the ocean, seas and marine resources.

Source: Company Website

+ NATURE CONSERVANCY FORGING A NEW PARTNERSHIP WITH E.O. WILSON BIODIVERSITY FOUNDATION

The Nature Conservancy and the E.O. Wilson Biodiversity Foundation announced today that a nearly 8,000-acre preserve in Alabama's Mobile-Tensaw Delta will be named in honor of famed natural scientist Edward Osborne Wilson. The announcement will be celebrated during a webinar discussion focused on the role community, culture and science play in caring for nature. The webinar takes place on June 10, 2025, what would have been Wilson's 96th birthday.

An internationally acclaimed leader for protecting biodiversity, Wilson's lifelong love for nature began with his childhood in Alabama. The E.O. Wilson Land Between the Rivers Preserve is in the heart of the Mobile-Tensaw Delta where he first explored his fascination with the natural world and later launched an unmatched legacy of education and conservation.

Source: Company Website

+ NATURE CONSERVANCY NEVADA PASSES TWO BILLS TO PRESERVE THE STATE'S GROUNDWATER FOR FUTURE GENERATIONS

In a move that marks a major step toward preserving water for the state's future, Nevada Governor Joe Lombardo signed two bills, Nevada Assembly Bill 104 (AB 104) and Senate Bill 36 (SB 36), into law. These bills establish the Nevada Voluntary Water Rights Retirement Program, a statewide initiative that enables groundwater rights holders, including agricultural producers, to voluntarily retire groundwater rights in areas where water use exceeds long-term water availability. They also create the Account for Retiring Water Rights, a dedicated fund within the Department of Conservation and Natural Resources, that will be used to purchase and retire groundwater rights. Once retired, these rights are permanently removed from use, helping stabilize aquifers and protect natural ecosystems.

Source: Company Website

+ NATURE CONSERVANCY A BLUEPRINT FOR RESILIENCE: NATURE-BASED SOLUTIONS FOR EUROPE'S WATER FUTURE

As the European Commission unveils its long-awaited Water Resilience Strategy, The Nature Conservancy (TNC) welcomes this pivotal step toward addressing Europe's growing water challenges. TNC calls on decision-makers to further ensure that nature-based solutions (NbS) stay at the core of the strategy's implementation, as essential tools to close Europe's widening water security gap and which benefit both people and nature.

Europe is already facing the consequences of water mismanagement and climate-driven extremes. According to the European Environment Agency's (EEA) Europe's State of Water Report, flooding causes EUR7 billion in damage yearly. By 2030, the continent could face a 56% shortfall between water supply and demand. In 2022, 41% of Europeans were affected by water scarcity, and nutrient pollution alone costs the EU EUR75 billion annually.

Source: Company Website

urn:contentItem:6GB6-5MY3-RRX7-N01Y-00000-00July 23, 2025: Dentons appointed by Singapore government for international carbon credit trading2025-07-23T00:00:00Z2025-09-09T21:08:37ZLexisNexisANNOUNCEMENTSJuly 23, 2025: Dentons appointed by Singapore government for international carbon credit trading

Dentons is honoured to be appointed by the Government of the Republic of Singapore to develop the model legal documents governing the international trading of carbon credits-an initiative enabled by Article 6 of the Paris Agreement. This engagement marks a significant milestone in global climate law and policy.

Singapore has long been a pioneer in implementing Article 6, recognising its pivotal role in accelerating global decarbonisation. As countries increasingly turn to voluntary cooperation to meet their climate targets, this project will establish the legal architecture necessary to support transparent, accountable, and effective carbon markets.

The winning proposal was led by Senior Partner Jonathan Guwe, who coordinated a cross-border team of Dentons lawyers including Senior Partner Emily Low, Partners Ng Teng Wei and Ho Jean Nie, Senior Associate Joey Tam and Associate Mason Sim from Singapore, Partner Jeffrey Fort from Chicago, Partner Hazel Saffery from Calgary, Partner Helen Bowdren from London, Managing Partner Claire Armstrong from Scotland, Partner Owen McLennan and Associate Sam Smart from Edinburg.

Dentons' selection followed a highly competitive global tendering process that drew proposals from many of the world's leading climate-focused law firms. The firm's successful bid was further strengthened by its collaboration with Pollination LLP, whose specialised expertise in Article 6, nature-based solutions, and voluntary carbon markets made Dentons the partner of choice for this landmark engagement.

This appointment underscores Dentons' commitment to advancing climate solutions through legal innovation and international cooperation.

urn:contentItem:6G74-P7G3-RRRF-B1F3-00000-00Patients would flock to our natural healing2025-07-09T00:00:00Z2025-09-09T21:08:37ZLexisNexisTALKINGPOINTPg. 22Patients would flock to our natural healingDr Andy Flies

Making Tasmania a destination for medical training would prevent and cure many ills, writes Dr Andy Flies Growing up in a small farming community near Rochester, Minnesota, in the US, the Mayo Clinic was a source of pride for many people in the region. The Mayo Clinic has been ranked as one of the best hospitals in the US, since 1990, and the best hospital in the world for the past seven years.

In 2015, Mayo launched the Destination Medical Centre (DMC) campaign to make Rochester a global medical destination. The plan included new biotechnology incubator precincts, regeneration of housing near healthcare facilities, and improved transportation networks from airports and regional communities. Rochester's success provides a model that Tasmania could follow for specialised medicine and economic development.

In 2025, Mayo employs 33,000 people in Rochester and generates $US1.5bn ($2.3bn) annual tax revenue. The larger Mayo Clinic health system has patients from more than 130 countries each year. Visitors provide a boost to the local economy each time they visit and pay out-of-pocket for the healthcare, rather than draining Medicare.

In addition to The Mayo Clinic, I have also worked at Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore, Maryland, which was the No. 1 ranked hospital in the US from 1991 to 2011. The striking difference was that Johns Hopkins was in the centre of a large industrial city, whereas Rochester was nestled into a midwestern farm community setting. This contrast shows that great healthcare can be delivered in very different socio-economic settings.

We have great people working in the Tasmanian health system, but resources are lacking in many key areas. The relatively new K Block building at the Royal Hobart Hospital was a great step forward.

When my youngest son was born, the K Block was basically a hole in the ground we could see out the window of the hospital. I watched the K Block rise and supply many design and construction jobs before diversifying into the hundreds of jobs needed to operate and maintain the new building. This made me wonder: Could Tasmania become a global medical destination?

Tasmania doesn't have a globally high-ranking hospital like The Mayo Clinic or Johns Hopkins as a foundation for a DMC. However, Tasmania is a unique and wonderful place to live and raise a family.

The true wilderness at our urban doorsteps in Tasmania is an experience to behold, and promotes outdoor lifestyles with great wellbeing benefits.

This wild beauty could be at the heart of a similar campaign here which could be titled Destination Medical Tasmania (DMT). Integrating what is special about Tasmania with current healthcare, research, and industry specialisations could make DMT a reality.

Specialisations are the key to developing a DMT; we can't be the best at everything, but we can be the best in some things and good in many others.

The University of Tasmania (UTAS) has world class neuroscience research and teaching programs. For example, UTAS has developed several massive online open courses (MOOCs) for dementia, multiple sclerosis, motor neurone disease, Parkinson's, and traumatic brain injury that have enrolled more than 500,000 participants from around the world since 2013.

Dementia was the second leading cause of death in Australia in 2023, and is one of the most challenging diseases for patients' families. Likewise, Tasmania has one of the highest multiple sclerosis rates in the world. A key aspect of specialty care for these debilitating neurological diseases would be teaching people how to care for their family members and themselves in the early stages of these debilitating diseases.

What better place to do this than Tasmania, with a view of kunanyi/Mt Wellington during the day and the gentle sounds of pademelons hopping around at night?

Nature-based solutions that not only extend lives, but also improve the quality of life for patients and families is an emerging field.

Programs like the dementia-inclusive nature hubs can help to address the growing need for dementia care and training. While dementia is one of the leading causes of death, mental health issues are among the most rapidly expanding quality of life issues on a global scale.

Nature based-solutions will play a key role in addressing mental health issues. Tasmania is an ideal setting to attract global patients and families to a DMT specialisation in nature-based solutions, which can fuel small businesses like "Nature. Be in it".

Additional specialisations could include One Health training centres, which focus on the links between human, animal, and environmental health, and trauma medicine to address the growing global popularity of Tasmania as a mountain biking and wilderness adventure destination.

As we are considering how to invest in the future of Tasmania, shouldn't we be considering what our most pressing needs are now and what they will be in the future? Such a Destination Medical Tasmania would ensure our health infrastructure supports our urban and regional communities, harness and conserve the omnipresent nature on our beautiful island, while contributing to a steady stream of well-paid, long-term jobs.

Dr Andy Flies is an Australian Research Council future fellow and associate professor of Immunology at the Menzies Institute for Medical Research, University of Tasmania

urn:contentItem:6GFT-18H3-RS76-B4F7-00000-00Updated: August 07, 2025: Global Center on Adaptation: President Duma Boko of Botswana Joins Global Center on Adaptation Board and other recent news2025-08-09T00:00:00Z2025-09-09T21:08:37ZLexisNexisANNOUNCEMENTSUpdated: August 07, 2025: Global Center on Adaptation: President Duma Boko of Botswana Joins Global Center on Adaptation Board and other recent news

The Global Center on Adaptation (GCA) is pleased to welcome Advocate Duma Boko, President of the Republic of Botswana to its Board, bringing to the table a renewed focus on climate justice, sustainable development and homegrown solutions for a continent on the frontline of the climate crisis.

INDEX

SECTION 1 PRESS RELEASES: 2025

SECTION 2 OTHER NEWS: 2025

SECTION 1 PRESS RELEASES: 2025

June 30: GCA Joins African Development Bank and Nigeria to Launch Transformational Agro-Industrial Program

R otterdam, Netherlands, 30 June 2025 - The Global Center on Adaptation (GCA) has joined forces with the Government of Nigeria and the African Development Bank (AfDB) to launch the second phase of the Special Agro-Industrial Processing Zones (SAPZ) Program, a landmark initiative set to reshape the future of Nigeria's agriculture sector. With a total investment of USD 975 million-including USD 600 million in AfDB financing-SAPZ Phase II is designed to boost climate-resilient infrastructure, drive inclusive industrialization, and unlock large-scale private sector investment across the agricultural value chain.

Source: Company Website

June 24: GCA Partners with World Bank on Climate-Smart Agricultural Program in Togo

July 29: GCA Launched Co-Design Workshop in Nairobi to Advance Urban Climate Resilience in Somalia

The Global Center on Adaptation (GCA), in collaboration with the World Bank, Somali government partners and GCA's training partner RedR UK, launched a multi-day Co-Design Workshop in Nairobi today to support climate-resilient urban development in Somalia. The workshop marks a key milestone in co-developing the Urban Climate Resilience Masterclass (UCRMC), a flagship training program designed to strengthen institutional capacity for climate adaptation in Somali cities.

July 22: GCA Commends Homa Bay's Leadership in Climate Resilience as People's Adaptation Plan Integrated with County Planning

The Global Center on Adaptation (GCA) today hailed Homa Bay County's bold leadership in transforming community-led climate action into official county planning, following a two-day visit by GCA President and CEO Professor Patrick V. Verkooijen to the lakeside county. His visit celebrated the integration of the People's Adaptation Plan into Homa Bay's official Local Physical and Land Use Development Plan-a landmark for locally led adaptation in Kenya. The visit, which included meetings with community leaders, informal traders, youth, and county officials, comes ahead of the formal launch of the People's Adaptation Plan in August, where Professor Verkooijen will participate in Kenya's Devolution Conference to showcase the model nationally.

July 12: Global Center on Adaptation: Togo Advances National Agricultural Insurance with GCA Support

The Government of Togo, in partnership with the Global Center on Adaptation (GCA) and Bioversity International and CIAT, has taken a major step forward in strengthening climate resilience for its farmers through the co-development of a National Agricultural Insurance Roadmap.

At a two-day workshop held in Lome on 10-11 July 2025, key stakeholders from across Togo's agriculture sector came together to finalize a comprehensive roadmap that will guide the rollout of index-based insurance for farmers. Participants included farming cooperatives, insurance providers, technical institutions, financial partners, and public agencies, all of whom contributed to a shared vision for a climate-smart agricultural insurance system.

Source: Company Website

July 09: Young people deliver a Communique to Global Leaders at the GCA High-Level Intergenerational Dialogue in Nairobi

Macky Sall, Chair of the Board of the Global Center on Adaptation (GCA); H.E. Ban Ki-moon, Honorary Chair of GCA's Board and Professor Patrick V. Verkooijen, President and CEO of GCA. The event underscored the critical role of young people in designing and implementing locally led climate resilience solutions across Africa.

July 08: Global Center on Adaptation Breaks Ground on Nairobi Headquarters, Becoming First International Organization with Dual Global South-North Headquarters

The new home of Climate Resilience to Showcase Iconic, Energy-Positive Design and Catalyze Co-Created Adaptation Solutions

Nairobi, Kenya, 8 July 2025 - Today the Global Center on Adaptation (GCA) marked a milestone in the fight against climate change by breaking ground on its new headquarters in Nairobi, Kenya-becoming the first international organization to maintain dual headquarters in both the Global South and Global North. This bold step underscores GCA's commitment to equal partnership between regions, recognizing that effective climate adaptation solutions must be co-designed and co-owned by communities across the world.

June 25: GCA Strengthens Climate-Resilient Urban Transport in Kigali

The Global Center on Adaptation (GCA) announced today a technical partnership with the World Bank's Rwanda Urban Mobility Improvement Project (RUMI) through the Africa Adaptation Acceleration Program, which aims to bolster the climate resilience of Kigali's rapidly evolving public transport network. Through this collaboration, GCA will undertake complementary climate risk assessments and develop adaptation guidelines to ensure that key transport assets-including the Nyabugogo multi-modal terminal and pilot Dedicated Bus Lanes (DBLs)-are designed to withstand future floods, landslides and extreme heat events

June 23: GCA to Provide Technical Support to Strengthen Climate-Resilient Infrastructure and Land Services in Cameroon

urn:contentItem:6G46-GHP3-RV34-Y0MB-00000-00WEEKLY RECAP: NATURE CONSERVANCY NEWS THIS PAST WEEK JUN 24, 20252025-06-25T00:00:00Z2025-09-09T21:08:37ZLexisNexisWEEKLY RECAP: NATURE CONSERVANCY NEWS THIS PAST WEEK JUN 24, 2025

+ NATURE CONSERVANCY [11 Press Releases]

+ THE NATURE CONSERVANCY RECEIVES GRANT TO PURCHASE NEW WATER TANK FOR PRESCRIBED FIRE MANAGEMENT

The Nature Conservancy (TNC) in Pennsylvania today announced it received new funding to support prescribed fire work in the Commonwealth. The Foxwynd Foundation awarded TNC a $10,000 grant to fund the purchase of a water tank and pump for fire suppression during controlled burns.

The new tank has the capacity to carry and pump approximately 70 gallons of water. It is outfitted to attach to off-road UTVs for transport into the backcountry forests of Pennsylvania.

Source: Company Website

+ NATURE CONSERVANCY TNC URGES OHIO LEGISLATURE TO FULLY FUND H2OHIO

The Nature Conservancy (TNC) today called on members of the Ohio Legislature to fully fund the H2Ohio program and continue a vital investment in the state's water quality and infrastructure.

"If H2Ohio isn't fully funded, it will cripple our state's ability to address the chronic harmful algal blooms that plague our waterways, including Lake Erie, and the outdoor recreation economy it supports," said Bill Stanley, state director for TNC in Ohio. "We are urging the Legislature to restore funding to this critical program and are encouraging Ohioans to contact your local lawmaker and tell them to fully fund H2Ohio."

Source: Company Website

+ NATURE CONSERVANCY RIGHTSIZING REFORESTATION: NEW MAPS SHOW WE CAN'T PUT TREES EVERYWHERE

From vast tracts of wilderness to city streets and our own backyards, restoring trees has long been recognised as a powerful option for limiting the impacts of global warming. Reforestation can absorb and store atmospheric carbon, while also supporting nature's recovery.

Source: Company Website

+ NATURE CONSERVANCY UVA WISE AND THE NATURE CONSERVANCY ANNOUNCE CUMBERLAND FOREST COMMUNITY FUND AWARD RECIPIENTS

The Cumberland Forest Community Fund is pleased to announce the recipients of its 2025 grant awards, with a total of $140,000 allocated to support seven impactful projects across Southwest Virginia. Selected through a competitive review process, these projects enhance environmental quality, strengthen community capacity and promote regional economic resilience.

"This year's awardees are driving crucial work in environmental stewardship, public access and placemaking," said Brad Kreps, director of The Nature Conservancy's Clinch Valley Program. "Their projects align with our mission to deepen connections between people and nature, creating lasting benefits like healthier ecosystems and vibrant community spaces. The impact of these funds, and their role in strengthening the capacity of each organization, grows every year as the Cumberland Forest Community Fund evolves."

Source: Company Website

+ NATURE CONSERVANCY GLOBAL INVESTMENTS IN NATURE-BASED SOLUTIONS FOR WATER SECURITY DOUBLED OVER THE PAST DECADE

The most comprehensive assessment ever published of money flowing into nature-based solutions (NbS) for water security reveals that total investment in this sector doubled over the decade 2013-2023-growing from ~US$22.4B in 2013 to ~$49B by the end of this timeframe.

Published by The Nature Conservancy (TNC) and Forest Trends, the new report Doubling Down on Nature: State of Investment in Nature-based Solutions for Water Security, 2025 underlines growing confidence in the power of these approaches among investors and policymakers. While the sector is dominated by government funding (97%), the findings highlight the accelerating rate at which private finance is rising while also showing how even major economic slowdowns like the COVID pandemic failed to dampen this growing interest.

Source: Company Website

+ THE NATURE CONSERVANCY CONSERVES SALMON HABITAT WITH LEMHI VALLEY CONSERVATION EASEMENT

Young Snake River salmon will have a better start in life thanks to a conservation easement recently secured by The Nature Conservancy (TNC) on the 181-acre Peterson Ranch in the Lemhi Valley. A conservation easement is a voluntary agreement that permanently protects the natural and ecological values of a property. Owners of the ranch agreed to restrict development on their property and committed to engage in significant river restoration efforts on Hayden Creek and the reach of the Lemhi River located on the ranch.

Source: Company Website

+ EVENTS CALENDAR: NATURE CONSERVANCY CEO STATEMENT: "FOSTERING A HEALTHY, RESILIENT OCEAN AT THE UN OCEAN CONFERENCE"

Ten years after COP21 and the Paris Agreement, the third UN Ocean Conference (UNOC3) will bring together UN Member States, specialized agencies, civil society, the private sector and international donors in Nice, France from June 9 to 13. Together, we will work to accelerate action to conserve and sustainably use the ocean, seas and marine resources.

Source: Company Website

+ NATURE CONSERVANCY FORGING A NEW PARTNERSHIP WITH E.O. WILSON BIODIVERSITY FOUNDATION

The Nature Conservancy and the E.O. Wilson Biodiversity Foundation announced today that a nearly 8,000-acre preserve in Alabama's Mobile-Tensaw Delta will be named in honor of famed natural scientist Edward Osborne Wilson. The announcement will be celebrated during a webinar discussion focused on the role community, culture and science play in caring for nature. The webinar takes place on June 10, 2025, what would have been Wilson's 96th birthday.

An internationally acclaimed leader for protecting biodiversity, Wilson's lifelong love for nature began with his childhood in Alabama. The E.O. Wilson Land Between the Rivers Preserve is in the heart of the Mobile-Tensaw Delta where he first explored his fascination with the natural world and later launched an unmatched legacy of education and conservation.

Source: Company Website

+ NATURE CONSERVANCY NEVADA PASSES TWO BILLS TO PRESERVE THE STATE'S GROUNDWATER FOR FUTURE GENERATIONS

In a move that marks a major step toward preserving water for the state's future, Nevada Governor Joe Lombardo signed two bills, Nevada Assembly Bill 104 (AB 104) and Senate Bill 36 (SB 36), into law. These bills establish the Nevada Voluntary Water Rights Retirement Program, a statewide initiative that enables groundwater rights holders, including agricultural producers, to voluntarily retire groundwater rights in areas where water use exceeds long-term water availability. They also create the Account for Retiring Water Rights, a dedicated fund within the Department of Conservation and Natural Resources, that will be used to purchase and retire groundwater rights. Once retired, these rights are permanently removed from use, helping stabilize aquifers and protect natural ecosystems.

Source: Company Website

+ NATURE CONSERVANCY A BLUEPRINT FOR RESILIENCE: NATURE-BASED SOLUTIONS FOR EUROPE'S WATER FUTURE

As the European Commission unveils its long-awaited Water Resilience Strategy, The Nature Conservancy (TNC) welcomes this pivotal step toward addressing Europe's growing water challenges. TNC calls on decision-makers to further ensure that nature-based solutions (NbS) stay at the core of the strategy's implementation, as essential tools to close Europe's widening water security gap and which benefit both people and nature.

Europe is already facing the consequences of water mismanagement and climate-driven extremes. According to the European Environment Agency's (EEA) Europe's State of Water Report, flooding causes EUR7 billion in damage yearly. By 2030, the continent could face a 56% shortfall between water supply and demand. In 2022, 41% of Europeans were affected by water scarcity, and nutrient pollution alone costs the EU EUR75 billion annually.

Source: Company Website

+ EVENTS CALENDAR: NATURE CONSERVANCY: UN OCEAN CONFERENCE TRIGGERS WAVE OF CONSERVATION COMMITMENTS AND HIGH SEAS TREATY RATIFICATIONS

Following the conclusion of the third United Nations Ocean Conference (UNOC3) in Nice, France, The Nature Conservancy's delegation lead and Global Ocean Director Dr. Lizzie McLeod shared her thoughts on the week's outcome:

"Last week, the world's ocean community came together in a powerful show of unity and resolve at UNOC3. Governments, Indigenous Peoples, civil society, scientists and the private sector united to call for urgent, inclusive and transformative ocean action. Their diverse voices echoed a common purpose: to ensure the ocean can continue its role as our planet's ultimate life-support system, sustaining food security, livelihoods, a stable climate and a wealth of incredible biodiversity.

Source: Company Website

urn:contentItem:6G82-57G3-RYHD-405R-00000-00Updated: July 09, 2025: BlueOrchard Finance Limited: BlueOrchard launches innovative public debt impact strategy, attracting investment from leading Japanese insurer and other recent news2025-07-13T00:00:00Z2025-09-09T21:08:37ZLexisNexisANNOUNCEMENTSUpdated: July 09, 2025: BlueOrchard Finance Limited: BlueOrchard launches innovative public debt impact strategy, attracting investment from leading Japanese insurer and other recent news

With a fund size of JPY 20 billion (USD 140 million), Orchard 2025 invests in impact bonds that promote environmental and social benefits, in accordance with Article 9 of the EU Sustainable Finance Disclosure Regulation (SFDR). These investments contribute to several UN Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). Orchard 2025's objectives emphasise allocating the substantial majority of its portfolio to sustainable investments that support the transition to a low-carbon economy and reduce carbon emissions through climate mitigation solutions. The Fund also invests in sustainable projects that enhance financial inclusion and improve access to essential services for underserved communities.

Zenkyoren's group company, Norinchukin Zenkyoren Asset Management Co., Ltd., serves as an investment advisor to the Fund, providing credit analysis, monitoring of portfolio constituents, and investment advice.

BlueOrchard, a pioneer in public markets impact investing, has recently surpassed the milestone of USD 1 billion in assets under management in its public debt strategies, underscoring the excellence of BlueOrchard's portfolio management approach. Orchard 2025 represents BlueOrchard's third innovative strategy in Japan, highlighting the company's capability to create strategies addressing client-specific needs. Additionally, the strategy offers significant flexibility through in USD, EURO, and GBP denominated public debt portfolio, using derivatives that allow the creation of stable cash flow streams in the investor's preferred currency.

SECTION 2 PRESS RELEASES: 2025

April 10: BlueOrchard appoints Michael Wehrle as Chief Executive Officer

The Board of BlueOrchard has appointed Michael Wehrle, Head of Investment Solutions & Private Equity at BlueOrchard and member of the Executive Management Team, as Chief Executive Officer, succeeding Philipp Mueller, subject to regulatory approval. BlueOrchard's Chief Impact and Blended Finance Officer, Maria Teresa Zappia, has been nominated to join the Board of Directors at the upcoming General Assembly, subject to pre-approval of the regulator.

Michael joined the business in 2021. He is currently responsible for overseeing the portfolio management and asset allocation of the firm's funds and mandates, as well as the development of product solutions. Additionally, he chairs several Investment Committees. Michael has over 20 years of comprehensive knowledge and substantial experience in the management of investments across public and private markets. Prior to joining BlueOrchard, Michael held various management roles at Partners Group in Switzerland and the UK. He is a CFA Charterholder and holds a Master's degree in Banking & Finance from the University of Zurich.

Source: Company Website

SECTION 3 OTHER NEWS: 2025

January 29: BlueOrchard Finance Limited: Nature-based Solutions: Fostering integrity for meaningful environmental and community benefits

Natural capital refers to the stock of natural resources (e.g. forests, plants, animals, air, water, soils, minerals) that combine to yield a flow of benefits to people[1], known as ecosystem services. These services fall into three main categories: provisioning services (such as food, timber, and energy), regulating and maintenance services (such as hazard protection), and cultural services (like tourism and well-being)[2]. Over the past few decades, human activities have led to a significant degradation of natural capital. It is estimated that approximately three-quarters of the Earth's land and nearly two-thirds of its marine environment have been substantially altered by human impact[3]. Nature-Based Solutions present a significant opportunity to halt this degradation and promote the regeneration of these vital resources, while simultaneously offering appealing investment opportunities. Source: Company Website

urn:contentItem:6GCN-G1T3-RTVD-82F2-00000-00WEEKLY RECAP: NATURE CONSERVANCY NEWS THIS PAST WEEK JUL 29, 20252025-07-30T00:00:00Z2025-09-09T21:08:37ZLexisNexisWEEKLY RECAP: NATURE CONSERVANCY NEWS THIS PAST WEEK JUL 29, 2025

+ NATURE CONSERVANCY [10 Press Releases]

+ THE NATURE CONSERVANCY IN NEVADA WELCOMES STEFANIE GIVENS AS NEW DIRECTOR OF DEVELOPMENT

he Nature Conservancy (TNC) in Nevada is announcing the appointment of Stefanie Givens as its new Director of Development. With a rich background in environmental education, nonprofit leadership, and fundraising, Stefanie brings a deep passion for conservation and a wealth of experience to her new role.

Source: Company Website

+ THE NATURE CONSERVANCY PLANTS 20TREES IN GROTON

It is only fitting that Shirley Dunbar Rose loves nature. And her appreciation goes far beyond the flower of her last name.

She was thrilled when she heard about a tree planting effort in her Connecticut neighborhood spearheaded by The Nature Conservancy. Residents of the City of Groton could sign up to receive a free tree in their yard, delivered and planted by TNC staff and volunteers, as well as municipal representatives.

"I just think that for the environment, it's great. That's why I'm interested. I like trees. I like nature. It's a wonderful program, and it's great the town is taking part," Rose said.

Source: Company Website

+ THE NATURE CONSERVANCY APPLAUDS GOVERNOR MURPHY AND LEGISLATIVE LEADERS FOR ENACTING WILDLIFE CORRIDOR LAW

In a resounding win for nature in New Jersey, Bill S3618/A4926 directing the New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection and the Department of Transportation to develop a statewide Wildlife Corridor Action Plan, was passed unanimously by the state legislature and immediately signed into law by Governor Phil Murphy. The Nature Conservancy thanks the governor for his swift action and commends Senator Bob Smith and Assemblyman Clinton Calabrese for their leadership in championing this critical legislation that ensures better connectivity for wildlife and safer roads for people.

Source: Company Website

+ THE NATURE CONSERVANCY AND WILLIS LAUNCH FIRST-OF-ITS-KIND WILDFIRE RESILIENCE INSURANCE

With California's wildfire crisis pushing the state's insurance industry to a breaking point, TNC/Willis launch innovative solution to improve insurance availability and affordability.

The Nature Conservancy (TNC) and Willis, a business of WTW (NASDAQ:WTW), announced today a first-of-its-kind insurance policy that takes into account efforts to mitigate fire risk. Structured by Willis, the $2.5 million wildfire resilience insurance coverage has been developed for Tahoe Donner Association (Tahoe Donner), a private homeowners association in Truckee, California. Source: Company Website

+ NATURE CONSERVANCY: UPDATED MARINE MAPPING TOOL OFFERS NEW FEATURES THAT SHARPEN THE FOCUS ON THE ATLANTIC OCEAN MARINE ECOSYSTEM

Today, The Nature Conservancy is announcing an update to its Northeast Marine Mapping Tool, a resource that can help inform ecosystem-based mitigation decisions and is designed to improve outcomes for marine life and habitats.

The ocean is a busy place. People use the ocean to ship goods, fish and harvest seafood, generate clean energy and more. Fish, whales, birds and other marine life also rely on habitats in the ocean and along the coast. To make the best choices about which mitigation actions are most useful for protecting and restoring marine life, decision-makers need to see the connections between species and their habitats both inside and outside of the ocean areas that people use.

Source: Company Website

+ NATURE CONSERVANCY: MONITORING FOR CHANGE: NEW REPORT REVEALS ELECTRONIC MONITORING AND WI-FI IMPROVE CREW WELFARE

A new report led by The Nature Conservancy and Conservation International shows significant promise in using electronic monitoring and Wi-Fi technologies to improve social responsibility across the global fishing industry. The groundbreaking report was informed by over a year's worth of research followed by a six-month pilot project during which electronic monitoring and Wi-Fi technologies were installed on tuna longline vessels based in the Western and Central Pacific to evaluate the feasibility of using these technology systems to monitor labor indicators (i.e., human rights violations, safety and working conditions), track progress towards social responsibility and research how electronic monitoring might integrate into a wider systems approach to improve crew welfare while at sea. Source: Company Website

+ THE NATURE CONSERVANCY APPOINTS SUZAN CRAIG DUNAND TO ITS GLOBAL BOARD OF DIRECTORS

The Nature Conservancy (TNC) announced the recent appointment of Suzan Craig Dunand as a member of its global Board of Directors.

"I am pleased to welcome Suzan Craig Dunand to our Global Board of Directors," said TNC CEO Jennifer Morris. "Suzan's commitment to making a meaningful difference for the planet is truly inspiring and she will play a pivotal role in advancing progress toward our 2030 Goals."

Source: Company Website

+ NATURE CONSERVANCY: TEXAS ACCEPTS FIRST DEDICATION OF WATER RIGHTS FOR ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION IN 20 YEARS

Texas Parks and Wildlife Department (TPWD) announces it has helped secure a 10-year commitment of 200 acre-feet per year of surface water to help conserve Big Cypress Bayou in northeast Texas.

The water right, purchased by The Nature Conservancy in Texas (TNC) and dedicated to the Texas Water Trust, will help TPWD manage habitat for native fish and mussels in Big Cypress Bayou, which flows into Caddo Lake. It will also support recreational opportunities downstream, where TPWD has partnered to establish ten paddling trails.

Source: Company Website

+ GLOBAL INVESTMENTS IN NATURE-BASED SOLUTIONS FOR WATER SECURITY DOUBLED OVER THE PAST DECADE

The most comprehensive assessment ever published of money flowing into nature-based solutions (NbS) for water security reveals that total investment in this sector doubled over the decade 2013-2023-growing from ~US$22.4B in 2013 to ~$49B by the end of this timeframe. Source: Company Website

The following is a statement by Dr. Katharine Hayhoe, The Nature Conservancy's chief scientist, after the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency announced actions to roll back safeguards designed to protect people and nature.

urn:contentItem:6G7N-5TG3-S9NN-0121-00000-00July 10, 2025: Events Calendar: University of Malta: Sustainable Ocean Futures: Presentation at the R&D Management Conference2025-07-12T00:00:00Z2025-09-09T21:08:37ZLexisNexisANNOUNCEMENTSJuly 10, 2025: Events Calendar: University of Malta: Sustainable Ocean Futures: Presentation at the R&D Management Conference

In early July the city of Pisa hosted the international R&D Management Conference, an annual international gathering that brings together researchers, professionals, and policymakers to explore current themes in innovation and research management. This year's focus on Innovation and Biodiversity reflected a growing recognition that addressing environmental challenges requires rethinking how we define and apply innovation to advance the sustainability and circular agendas.

Dr Lisa Pace from The Edward de Bono Institute for Creative Thinking and Innovation presented her work at the conference on 'Harnessing nature-based solutions for sustainable ocean futures'. "It is interesting to see management and innovation scholars collaborating with natural scientists on topics as diverse as biodiversity accounting, sustainable value chains and business models", said Dr Lisa Pace.

The work that Dr Pace presented reflects preliminary findings from the POSEIDON project on 'Exploring Pathways tOward Sustainable ocEan futures: tensIons, traDe-offs, and just transitiONs' that aims to explore sustainability futures as strategic courses of action or pathways adopted by various actors to transition from present conditions towards preferred future visions or clearly defined objectives.

"We often think of sustainability as a desirable end goal; but there are also unintended outcomes from scaling sustainability initiatives that needed to be considered", Dr Pace said. "As the research from the POSEIDON project progresses, we hope to offer insights that can inform both academic debates and practical approaches to sustainable development in coastal areas".

Farmland in the Netherlands is in short supply, while demand continues to grow. That demand comes not only from the agricultural sector, but also from housing, infrastructure, business parks and renewable energy projects.

The value of land also depends on what it can yield financially-its 'earning capacity'. This in turn is affected by technological advancements, increasingly intensive land use, and the prices farmers receive for their produce.

SECTION 2 PRESS RELEASES: 2025

June 20: Wageningen University & Research: Earthworm Farming for Circular Food Systems: Upcycling Residual Biomass into Edible Protein and Organic Soil Amendments

This PhD research explores how agricultural waste, such as leftover maize stalks, can be transformed into valuable food and natural fertilizer through a combination of mushroom cultivation and earthworm farming. First, oyster mushrooms are grown on maize stover, producing protein-rich food using a widely available and low-cost substrate. The spent mushroom material then feeds earthworms, which convert it into additional high-quality protein and nutrient-rich compost. Farmed earthworms were found to have a protein content and amino acid profile comparable to or better than commonly farmed insects, making them a promising alternative protein source. At the same time, the compost they produce helps maintain soil carbon content-without the need for extra land. This circular system could strengthen local food security and support soil health in maize-based farming systems across Sub-Saharan Africa, particularly in the face of population growth, land scarcity, and climate-related stress.

Source: Company Website

June 20: Wageningen University & Research: Light, Roots, and Nutrients: Understanding Nitrate Uptake Regulation in Hydroponic Systems

My PhD research explored nitrate uptake regulation in hydroponics-a system where plants grow in nutrient-rich water without soil, offering sustainable production potential. Experiments with Arabidopsis showed that plants absorb most of the available nitrate but retain only what is needed, releasing the rest back almost simultaneously-a dynamic balance between uptake and use. Plants also prioritize internal nitrogen balance by adjusting allocation between root and shoot, rather than reacting immediately to external changes. Mechanical disturbance of roots, common in hydroponic systems due to oxygenation, significantly reduced growth without affecting nitrate uptake. After conducting extensive hydroponic experiments, I recognized the need for a practical tool to support hydroponic system planning. I developed a dynamic model that estimates how long a setup can sustain plant growth, and whether issues like rising EC, nutrient depletion, or imbalanced nutrient ratios may occur under different environmental conditions, system sizes, and replenishment strategies.

Source: Company Website

SECTION 3 OTHER NEWS: 2025

July 04: Wageningen University & Research: NWA funding for research into quinoa, lupin and aardaker: promising meat alternatives that also benefit the soil

A plate of vegetables that not only nourishes people but also helps restore biodiversity, improve soil health and make our diets more climate-friendly. That is exactly what a new Dutch research project, led by Wageningen University & Research, aims to achieve. The project has been awarded nearly 6.8 million euros in funding from the Dutch Research Agenda (Nationale Wetenschapsagenda, NWA).

Under the name REAP2SOW, a consortium of farmers, scientists, companies and societal partners is working together to build a more sustainable food system. The focus is on three crops that are still relatively unknown in the Netherlands: white lupin, quinoa and the 'forgotten vegetable' aardaker. These crops offer multiple benefits: they are resilient to climate change, provide high-quality plant proteins from seeds or tubers and contribute to healthier soils. The roots of lupin and aardaker can also fix nitrogen, reducing the need for artificial fertilisers.

Source: Company Website

July 01: Wageningen University & Research: From university idea to EdTech success: the spin-off story of Wageningen University & Research and Peek

How does a successful spin-off emerge from a university setting? As part of the Co-Creation Lab, where we explore the conditions and success factors for effective co-creation, we spoke with Maurits Burgering (Wageningen University & Research) and Gerwald van de Munt (Peek) about how a local educational challenge evolved into a widely applicable EdTech solution.

Peek is a company that originated from a concrete problem faced by a university lecturer: field trips are valuable, but often time-consuming and labour-intensive. Moreover, it can be difficult to assess their true impact, are participants genuinely learning? This challenge sparked the idea for an app that enables interactive excursions, allowing users to learn actively about landscapes and their surroundings. That idea eventually developed into an independent and innovative EdTech company, with Wageningen University & Research (WUR) as one of its clients.

Source: Company Website

June 30: Wageningen University & Research: Youth Take the Lead in Nature-Based Food System Solutions

With the accelerating impacts of climate change, biodiversity loss, and food insecurity, countries around the world are urgently rethinking the way food is produced, processed, and consumed. One promising approach rising to the forefront is Nature-based Solutions (NBS), which are strategies that work with ecosystems to address societal challenges while enhancing resilience, sustainability, and equity.

In this context, the 2025 Food Systems Innovation Challenge - Nature-based Solutions edition invites student teams from 12 countries to co-create and implement NbS projects tailored to their local realities. Organised by Wageningen University & Research (WUR) and the Netherlands Food Partnership (NFP), the challenge aims to nurture entrepreneurial thinking and hands-on learning among future food system leaders.

Nature-based solutions are increasingly critical in addressing food security and climate issues," explains Mirjam Troost, coordinator from WUR. "We want to share our knowledge from WUR and help spread awareness of the importance of applying NBS in food systems, especially through youth engagement

Source: Company Website

urn:contentItem:6G9Y-23C3-RRYP-Y2NM-00000-00July 11, 2025: Stanford University: Leveraging the tools of finance to achieve sustainable development2025-07-22T00:00:00Z2025-09-09T21:08:37ZLexisNexisANNOUNCEMENTSJuly 11, 2025: Stanford University: Leveraging the tools of finance to achieve sustainable development

At least half of global GDP is moderately or highly dependent on nature. S&P Global estimates that 85% of companies in the S&P Global 1200 directly depend on nature. More than 75% of food crops rely on pollinators, and healthy ecosystems generate 75% of global freshwater, as noted by the World Health Organization. Yet despite this dependence, human activities are driving an unprecedented decline in ecosystems. We are losing species at 1,000 times the natural rate. According to insurer Swiss Re, one-fifth of the world's countries are at risk of ecosystem collapse. And we are all interconnected: if the Amazon Rainforest were completely deforested, the impact on weather cycles would reduce Sierra Nevada snowpack by half - a critical water source for Californians and for food supplies across the United States.

Billions of dollars must be redirected to retain all the aspects of ecosystems that provide services essential to sustaining life. Many terms are used for this central challenge of mobilizing funding to address the interconnected global crises of nature loss and climate change. Green finance. Nature finance. Climate finance. Sustainable finance. Governments around the world currently pay 82% of the $200 billion per year going toward nature-based solutions - but they cannot bridge the financing gap on their own.

urn:contentItem:6GJB-V2S3-RV89-P142-00000-00WEEKLY RECAP: UNIVERSITY OF RHODE ISLAND NEWS THIS PAST WEEK AUG 20, 20252025-08-21T00:00:00Z2025-09-09T21:08:37ZLexisNexisWEEKLY RECAP: UNIVERSITY OF RHODE ISLAND NEWS THIS PAST WEEK AUG 20, 2025

+ UNIVERSITY OF RHODE ISLAND [6 Press Releases]

+ URI TO HOST TWO-DAY NEURODIVERSITY CONFERENCE FEATURING RENOWNED AUTISM ADVOCATE TEMPLE GRANDIN

The University of Rhode Island is set to host the Northeast Regional Higher Education Neurodiversity Coalition Conference for the inaugural time this summer. Scheduled for August 29 and 30, the event will take place at URI's Fascitelli Center for Advanced Engineering, located at 2 East Alumni Ave. on the Kingston Campus. Among the highlighted keynote speakers is Dr. Temple Grandin, a respected animal behavioral scientist, bestselling author, and a prominent advocate for individuals with autism spectrum disorders. "Dr. Grandin's early career success as an animal scientist was because she thought differently and saw things that others did not see," says Anthony Marchese, the dean of the College of Engineering at URI.

+ UNIVERSITY OF RHODE ISLAND HIGHLIGHTS RISING VACCINE EXEMPTIONS AND ASSOCIATED RISKS FOR SCHOOLCHILDREN

Despite the established safety and effectiveness of vaccines in preventing communicable diseases, vaccination rates among young students have been on a gradual decline in recent years as more parents opt for exemptions from school vaccine mandates. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, exemption requests reached unprecedented levels last year, with a record 3.6 percent of kindergarten students being exempted from vaccine requirements, an increase from 3.3 percent the previous year. The CDC reports that only 92.5 percent of kindergarteners were vaccinated against highly infectious diseases such as measles, rubella, and mumps during the 2024-25 school year. Prior to the COVID-19 pandemic, vaccination rates among kindergartners were above 95 percent, a threshold necessary to prevent outbreaks.

+ UNIVERSITY OF RHODE ISLAND PROFESSOR RECEIVES NSF GRANT TO EXPLORE NATURE-BASED SOLUTIONS FOR COASTAL HAZARDS

According to the Coastal Resources Management Council, Rhode Island's coastline is eroding at an alarming rate of nearly two feet per year, with certain regions experiencing losses exceeding that figure. The most significant erosion is occurring in high-energy wave zones along the state's southern coast, which is particularly vulnerable due to its exposure. Recently, Che-Wei Chang, an Assistant Professor at the University of Rhode Island, has secured a National Science Foundation grant for his research project titled Experimental Investigation of Vegetation Effects on Coastal Wave and Current Dynamics. "Our research addresses the growing need for effective and sustainable shoreline protection strategies," said Chang, a professor in the ocean engineering department. "By understanding how coastal vegetation interacts with waves and currents, we can better evaluate its role in protecting coastal communities."

+ URI INTRODUCES NEW ACADEMIC PROGRAMS FOR THE 2025-26 ACADEMIC YEAR

The University of Rhode Island will commence its fall semester classes on Sept. 3, unveiling a range of new academic programs for the upcoming academic year. Among the new undergraduate offerings is a B.A. in Business Studies, an online RN to BSN degree, and an online Interdisciplinary Studies major. Additionally, five new master's degrees will be introduced this fall in areas such as Management, Educational Leadership and Policy, Public Health, Mental and Behavioral Health Counseling, and Engineering Management & Leadership. Two new graduate certificates in College Teaching and Community Planning will also be available. The URI Graduate School has experienced an 11% rise in fall applications compared to the previous year, and a significant 29% increase from two years ago, with over 5,300 inquiries regarding the University's graduate programs.

+ UNIVERSITY OF RHODE ISLAND STUDIES ALASKAN SALT MARSHES FOR INSIGHTS INTO DYNAMIC COASTAL ECOSYSTEMS

The most powerful earthquake in U.S. history struck Alaska's south coast on March 27, 1964, registering a magnitude of 9.2 on the Richter scale. This seismic event triggered a tsunami that affected regions as far south as California and significantly transformed the Alaskan landscape. When the earthquake modified the elevation of land in areas like Anchorage and the Copper River Delta, it resulted in a complex new coastal wetland landscape. Since then, salt marshes have reestablished themselves, creating vital habitats for species such as shorebirds, salmon, beaver, and moose. These wetlands play a crucial role in wildlife support, coastal flood mitigation, pollutant filtration, nutrient distribution, and carbon sequestration, yet there remain unanswered questions regarding their geological and ecological characteristics.

+ URI STUDENT OVERCOMES ADVERSITY WHILE PURSUING PASSION FOR SHIPWRECK EXPLORATION

Inspired by his father's career as a naval architect, Jake Bonney has aspired to work in ocean science since childhood. "Growing up, I went into the office with him and tagged along on boat launches and stability tests," said Bonney. "My father printed out drawings of the ships he was working on, and I colored them in." Years later, Bonney's father joined him on visits to universities that offered ocean engineering programs. Ultimately, he chose to enroll at the University of Rhode Island.

urn:contentItem:6G7K-PBW3-RWH1-72CM-00000-00Updated: July 04, 2025: Wageningen University & Research: NWA funding for research into quinoa, lupin and aardaker: promising meat alternatives that also benefit the soil and other recent news2025-07-11T00:00:00Z2025-09-09T21:08:37ZLexisNexisANNOUNCEMENTSUpdated: July 04, 2025: Wageningen University & Research: NWA funding for research into quinoa, lupin and aardaker: promising meat alternatives that also benefit the soil and other recent news

A plate of vegetables that not only nourishes people but also helps restore biodiversity, improve soil health and make our diets more climate-friendly. That is exactly what a new Dutch research project, led by Wageningen University & Research, aims to achieve. The project has been awarded nearly 6.8 million euros in funding from the Dutch Research Agenda (Nationale Wetenschapsagenda, NWA).

Under the name REAP2SOW, a consortium of farmers, scientists, companies and societal partners is working together to build a more sustainable food system. The focus is on three crops that are still relatively unknown in the Netherlands: white lupin, quinoa and the 'forgotten vegetable' aardaker. These crops offer multiple benefits: they are resilient to climate change, provide high-quality plant proteins from seeds or tubers and contribute to healthier soils. The roots of lupin and aardaker can also fix nitrogen, reducing the need for artificial fertilisers.

SECTION 2 PRESS RELEASES: 2025

June 20: Wageningen University & Research: Earthworm Farming for Circular Food Systems: Upcycling Residual Biomass into Edible Protein and Organic Soil Amendments

This PhD research explores how agricultural waste, such as leftover maize stalks, can be transformed into valuable food and natural fertilizer through a combination of mushroom cultivation and earthworm farming. First, oyster mushrooms are grown on maize stover, producing protein-rich food using a widely available and low-cost substrate. The spent mushroom material then feeds earthworms, which convert it into additional high-quality protein and nutrient-rich compost. Farmed earthworms were found to have a protein content and amino acid profile comparable to or better than commonly farmed insects, making them a promising alternative protein source. At the same time, the compost they produce helps maintain soil carbon content-without the need for extra land. This circular system could strengthen local food security and support soil health in maize-based farming systems across Sub-Saharan Africa, particularly in the face of population growth, land scarcity, and climate-related stress.

Source: Company Website

June 20: Wageningen University & Research: Light, Roots, and Nutrients: Understanding Nitrate Uptake Regulation in Hydroponic Systems

My PhD research explored nitrate uptake regulation in hydroponics-a system where plants grow in nutrient-rich water without soil, offering sustainable production potential. Experiments with Arabidopsis showed that plants absorb most of the available nitrate but retain only what is needed, releasing the rest back almost simultaneously-a dynamic balance between uptake and use. Plants also prioritize internal nitrogen balance by adjusting allocation between root and shoot, rather than reacting immediately to external changes. Mechanical disturbance of roots, common in hydroponic systems due to oxygenation, significantly reduced growth without affecting nitrate uptake. After conducting extensive hydroponic experiments, I recognized the need for a practical tool to support hydroponic system planning. I developed a dynamic model that estimates how long a setup can sustain plant growth, and whether issues like rising EC, nutrient depletion, or imbalanced nutrient ratios may occur under different environmental conditions, system sizes, and replenishment strategies.

Source: Company Website

SECTION 3 OTHER NEWS: 2025

July 01: Wageningen University & Research: From university idea to EdTech success: the spin-off story of Wageningen University & Research and Peek

How does a successful spin-off emerge from a university setting? As part of the Co-Creation Lab, where we explore the conditions and success factors for effective co-creation, we spoke with Maurits Burgering (Wageningen University & Research) and Gerwald van de Munt (Peek) about how a local educational challenge evolved into a widely applicable EdTech solution.

Peek is a company that originated from a concrete problem faced by a university lecturer: field trips are valuable, but often time-consuming and labour-intensive. Moreover, it can be difficult to assess their true impact, are participants genuinely learning? This challenge sparked the idea for an app that enables interactive excursions, allowing users to learn actively about landscapes and their surroundings. That idea eventually developed into an independent and innovative EdTech company, with Wageningen University & Research (WUR) as one of its clients.

Source: Company Website

June 30: Wageningen University & Research: Youth Take the Lead in Nature-Based Food System Solutions

With the accelerating impacts of climate change, biodiversity loss, and food insecurity, countries around the world are urgently rethinking the way food is produced, processed, and consumed. One promising approach rising to the forefront is Nature-based Solutions (NBS), which are strategies that work with ecosystems to address societal challenges while enhancing resilience, sustainability, and equity.

In this context, the 2025 Food Systems Innovation Challenge - Nature-based Solutions edition invites student teams from 12 countries to co-create and implement NbS projects tailored to their local realities. Organised by Wageningen University & Research (WUR) and the Netherlands Food Partnership (NFP), the challenge aims to nurture entrepreneurial thinking and hands-on learning among future food system leaders.

Nature-based solutions are increasingly critical in addressing food security and climate issues," explains Mirjam Troost, coordinator from WUR. "We want to share our knowledge from WUR and help spread awareness of the importance of applying NBS in food systems, especially through youth engagement

Source: Company Website

June 30: Wageningen University & Research: Animal-Friendly Livestock Farming Covenant signed

The Animal-Friendly Livestock Farming Covenant follows on from the Animals Act adopted last year, which stipulates that animal husbandry must be 'humane' by 2040 at the latest. The exact meaning of this concept has been specified in sector plans for the four largest sectors: pigs, poultry, cows, and a plan for calves that is still to be finalized. Legally, the agreements are enshrined in a so-called Order in Council, which has been open for consultation since last week.

WUR is one of the parties that has been consulted. Quite a precarious role, according to Livestock researcher Karel de Greef: 'Our task is to investigate and, on that basis, interpret how animals function, how they experience things, how animal husbandry can accommodate this and whether - and how - any shortcomings can be compensated for. We can indicate the bandwidths: when do we see signs of positive welfare in animals, at what values do we observe discomfort, and at what point can there be damage to welfare or health? But ultimately, it is up to politicians to set the standard.'

'Setting standards is a political choice,' agrees animal researcher Fleur Hoorweg, 'but the scientific perspective is necessary in order to set standards properly.
